newsitem.title: JAPAN: NEC says April-Sept chip production falls 4.0%.
newsitem.headline: NEC says April-Sept chip production falls 4.0%.

text.p: NEC Corp senior executive vice president Hajime Sasaki said on Monday that the firm's chip production in the first half of this business year fell 4.0 percent against the year-earlier period to 530 billion yen.
He also said the value of the company's chip production would drop 6.0 percent to 1.1 trillion yen in the full business year to the end of March 1997.

He told a news conference that prices of 16-megabit dynamic random access memories (DRAMs) had stabilised and that a large fall was unlikely in the January-March quarter, despite analysts' predictions that the market could fall after higher sales for the Christmas season.
"We anticipate prices of a 16-megabit DRAMs will stay above $10 in the second half of the current business year," Sasaki said.
"Pricing such as seven or eight dollars per chip (as reported by the media) is impossible," he said.
Currently, there was a supply shortage for some 16-megabit DRAM products as demand was being stepped up ahead of the Christmas season, he said.
Sasaki said he expected strong demand for memory chips to continue into early next year, helped by the Internet boom and increasing use of memory-hungry Windows NT operating software.

Sasaki said an estimated six percent drop in NEC's chip production in the current business year would lead to "a considerable decline in profit" in the company's semiconductor business, but declined to comment on specific figures.

NEC would revise downward its planned capital investment in the microchip business in 1996/97 to 190 billion yen from the 210 billion yen it originally estimated at the start of the year, Sasaki said.
The basic investment programme, however, would not be changed, he said.
